articles.headline: Judge Strikes Down Arkansas Law Banning Gender Transition Care for Minors
articles.snippet: The case had been closely watched as an important test of whether bans on transition care for minors, enacted by more than a dozen states, could withstand challenges.
articles.abstract: The case had been closely watched as an important test of whether bans on transition care for minors, enacted by more than a dozen states, could withstand challenges.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Arkansas on Tuesday struck down the state’s law forbidding medical treatments for children and teenagers seeking gender transitions, blocking what had been the first in a wave of such measures championed by conservative lawmakers across the country.
articles.byline: By Rick Rojas and Emily Cochrane

articles.headline: Why Is Narendra Modi So Popular? Tune In to Find Out.
articles.snippet: The Indian leader, who visits Washington this week, has softened his image at home with an old-fashioned radio show, which feeds a vast social media apparatus.
articles.abstract: The Indian leader, who visits Washington this week, has softened his image at home with an old-fashioned radio show, which feeds a vast social media apparatus.
articles.lead_paragraph: Once a month, India’s prime minister, Narendra Modi, walks into a studio set up at his government bungalow and takes his seat behind a microphone. The air-conditioning is switched off to quiet its hum. Thick curtains maintain the room’s silence even from Mr. Modi’s favorite peacocks in the garden outside.

articles.headline: This Salon Works to Understand Black Women’s Hair
articles.snippet: Each week, the global conglomerate Unilever brings people into a salon to test new products. It’s hoping to get a bigger piece of the long undervalued but growing Black beauty market.
articles.abstract: Each week, the global conglomerate Unilever brings people into a salon to test new products. It’s hoping to get a bigger piece of the long undervalued but growing Black beauty market.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a recent spring afternoon, Marcella Roberts and Brooke Council sat in a salon chatting about how much they liked their hair. The two women, who are Black, were discussing a new cream they had been using to style and moisturize their curly hairstyles.

articles.headline: Is the Inflation Battle Won? Not Yet.
articles.snippet: Inflation has come down from its 2022 heights, but economists are worried about its stubbornness.
articles.abstract: Inflation has come down from its 2022 heights, but economists are worried about its stubbornness.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inflation is beginning to abate meaningfully for American consumers. Gas is cheaper, eggs cost roughly half as much as they did in January and prices are no longer climbing as rapidly across a wide array of products.

articles.headline: How It Feels to Have Your Life Changed By Affirmative Action
articles.snippet: Black and Hispanic college graduates, whose lives were directly shaped by race-conscious college admissions, have complicated thoughts about the expected Supreme Court decision.
articles.abstract: Black and Hispanic college graduates, whose lives were directly shaped by race-conscious college admissions, have complicated thoughts about the expected Supreme Court decision.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a top student at his Philadelphia high school in 1968, Granderson Hale knew he stood a decent chance of admission at one of the historically Black colleges that typically sent recruiters to the school, where nearly all of the 2,700 students were Black.

articles.headline: Fed Chair Sees ‘Long Way to Go’ on Inflation Fight
articles.snippet: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, told House lawmakers that most central bank officials expect rates to rise further.
articles.abstract: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, told House lawmakers that most central bank officials expect rates to rise further.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, told House lawmakers that the United States remains a “long way” away from low and stable inflation even 15 months into the central bank’s campaign to cool the economy and wrestle down rapid price increases.

articles.headline: F.T.C. Accuses Amazon of Tricking Users Into Subscribing to Prime
articles.snippet: The lawsuit is the first time that the Federal Trade Commission under its chair, Lina Khan, has taken Amazon to court.
articles.abstract: The lawsuit is the first time that the Federal Trade Commission under its chair, Lina Khan, has taken Amazon to court.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission sued Amazon on Wednesday, accusing it of illegally inducing consumers to sign up for its Prime service and then hindering them from canceling the subscription, in the most aggressive action against the company to date by the agency’s chair, Lina Khan.

articles.headline: Student Loan Pause Is Ending, With Consequences for Economy
articles.snippet: Three years of relief from payments on $1.6 trillion in student debt allowed for other borrowing and spending — and will shift into reverse.
articles.abstract: Three years of relief from payments on $1.6 trillion in student debt allowed for other borrowing and spending — and will shift into reverse.
articles.lead_paragraph: A bedrock component of pandemic-era relief for households is coming to an end: The debt-limit deal struck by the White House and congressional Republicans requires that the pause on student loan payments be lifted no later than Aug. 30.
